citations.narrative:
-The primary enclosure for the 8 alpaca and single nilgai is in disrepair. The fence posts and fence on the north side of
the enclosure are leaning severely to the inside of the enclosure.
-The primary enclosure for 4 zebu and 4 llama has a gate that has an 18" gap at the bottom from the tractor and water
eroding the soil underneath.
The indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the
animals from injury and to contain the animals.
Ensure all housing facilities are maintained in good repair to protect and contain the animals inside the enclosure.

-The primary enclosure for the nilgai does not have a perimeter fence.
On or after May 17, 2000, all outdoor housing facilities (i.e., facilities not entirely indoors) must be enclosed by a perimeter
fence that is of sufficient height to keep animals and unauthorized persons out. Fences less than 6 feet high for non-
dangerous animals must be approved in writing by the Administrator. The fence must be constructed so that it protects
the animals in the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized persons from going through it or under it and having
contact with the animals in the facility, and so that it can function as a secondary containment system for the animals in
the facility. It must be of sufficient distance from the outside of the primary enclosure to prevent physical contact between
animals inside the enclosure and animals or persons outside the perimeter fence. Such fences less than 3 feet in distance
from the primary enclosure must be approved in writing by the Administrator.
Ensure all animals that require a perimeter fence have a perimeter fence.

There is a large accumulation of urine and feces in the primary enclosure for the male wallaby.
Excreta shall be removed from primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent contamination of the animals
contained therein and to minimize disease hazards and to reduce odors.
Clean primary enclosures as often as necessary to reduce odor, disease hazards, and pest infestation.

There is a large accumulation of various fencing materials in the primary enclosure for the 4 llama and 4 zebu.
Premises (buildings and grounds) shall be kept clean and in good repair in order to protect the animals from injury and to
facilitate the prescribed husbandry practices set forth in this subpart.
Excess building materials must be stored outside of primary enclosures to protect the animals from injury.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
KURT HAMMEL, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
